sn11.11:1.2: The oldest stories of Indra already evidence a shift from the violent victory over the serpent Vṛtra (see SN 2.3:3.4) to his liberating the Vala cave, which he did by the power of truth in his role as bṛhaspa﻿ti, the “lord of hymns”. Curiously, just as this discourse follows one featuring Sambara, later legend connects Indra’s power in this life to advice he received from Sambara in the past; namely, to always honor and respect brahmins (Mahābhārata 13.36).
sn11.11:1.3: The seven vows and following verses also appear in the next two discourses.
sn11.11:2.1: Here jantu shows its original meaning of “one who is born”, namely a human child.
